g.name: Gram
g.description: unit of mass defined as 1e-3 kg

Da.name: Dalton
Da.description: Sometimes called an atomic mass unit, defined as 1/12 of the mass of an unbound neutral atom of carbon-12 in its nuclear and electronic ground state and at rest

grain.name: Grain
grain.description: Mass approximately equivalent to a single ideal seed of a cereal, in particular wheat or barley

ozm.name: Ounce
ozm.description: US and Imperial unit equal to 1/16 of a Pound Mass

dram.name: Dram
dram.description: Unit of mass historically used by apothecaries equal to 1/16 of an ounce

lbm.name: Pound
lbm.description: US and Imperial primary unit of mass

stone.name: Stone
stone.description: Imperial unit equal to 14 Pounds Mass

sg.name: Slug
sg.description: US and Imperial unit defined as 1 lbf / Standard Gravity

cwt.name: Short Hundredweight
cwt.description: Typically used in the US, equal to 100 lbm

dwt.name: Short Pennyweight
dwt.description: From the weight of an English penny in the Middle Ages, equal to 24 grains or 1/20 of a troy ounce

uk_cwt.name: Long Hundredweight
uk_cwt.description: Typically used in the UK, equal to 8 stone

ton.name: Ton
ton.description: US customary unit equal to 2000 lbm

uk_ton.name: UK Ton
uk_ton.description: English customary unit that is equal to 20 Long Hundredweight or 160 Stone

metric_ton.name: Metric Ton
metric_ton.description: Sometimes seen as 'tonne', this mass equals 1000 kg

carat.name: Carat
carat.description: Equal to 200 mg, typically used to measure gemstones

assay_ton.name: Assay Ton
assay_ton.description: Equal to 29 1/6 grams, often used to measure the ores of precious metals

denier.name: Denier
denier.description: Linear density used in textiles, the linear density of a single strand of silk is approx. 1 denier

tex.name: Tex
tex.description: Linear density equal to 1 g / km, mainly used for measuring fiber products

ang.name: Angstrom
ang.description: Equal to 10^-10 meters, often used to express the size of atoms and molecules

picapt.name: Pica Point
picapt.description: Used in typography, equal to 1/12 of a pica

pica.name: Pica
pica.description: Used in typography, equal to 1/6 of an inch

in.name: Inch
in.description: US and Imperial unit of length equal to 1/12 of a foot

mil.name: Mil
mil.description: US and Imperial units for milli-inch, avoids a unit collision with the unit 'min'

ft.name: Foot
ft.description: Standard US and Imperial unit of length

yd.name: Yard
yd.description: US and Imperial unit of length equal to 3 foot

ell.name: Ell
ell.description: Formerly used in the english tayloring industry and defined as a yard and a quarter, now obsolete

mi.name: Mile
mi.description: US and Imperial measure of distance equal to 5280 feet or 1,609.344 meters

survey_mi.name: Survey Mile
survey_mi.description: US Customary unit equal to 5280 Survey Feet

nmi.name: Nautical Mile
nmi.description: Approximately 1/60 of a degree of latitude, formally defined as 1852 meters

league.name: League
league.description: Originally represented the distance a person could walk in one day, the most recent common usage was in maritime where it is equal to 3 nautical miles

ly.name: Light Year
ly.description: Represents the distance light travels in one year in a vacuum, used in astronomical scales

survey_ft.name: Survey Foot
survey_ft.description: Slightly different definition of foot defined as 1200/3937 meters instead of 0.3048 meters

AU.name: Astronomical Unit
AU.description: Approximate distance from the Earth to the Sun

chain.name: Chain
chain.description: US customary unit equal to 66 survey ft, sometimes the unit may be based on the internation foot rather than the survey foot changing the definition slightly

link.name: Link
link.description: US Customary unit of length equal to 1/100 of a chain

rod.name: Rod
rod.description: US Customary unit of length equal to 1/4 of a chain

furlong.name: Furlong
furlong.description: US Customary unit of length equal to 10 chains

fathom.name: Fathom
fathom.description: Equal to 6 international foot, typically used to measure depth in maritime applications

us_fathom.name: US Fathom
us_fathom.description: US Customary Fathom, appox. equal to 6 survey foot

fermi.name: Fermi
fermi.description: Equal to 10^-15 m, Used in nuclear physics and named after physicist Enrico Fermi who was one of the founders of the field

datamile.name: Data Mile
datamile.description: A distance used in radar measurements equal to 6000 international feet

kayser.name: Kayser/Wavenumber
kayser.description: Reciprocal of 1 cm, used in spectroscopy and chemistry to represent the number of wavelengths per cm

s.name: Second
s.description: Approximately 1/86400 of a stellar day, formally defined based on the duration of 9 192 631 770 state transitions of the caesium-133 atom at 0 K

day.name: Day
day.description: Approximately equal to the amount of time for the earth to rotate on it's axis, formally defined as 24 hours

fortnight.name: Fortnight
fortnight.description: Amount of time defined as 2 weeks or 14 days

yr.name: Year
yr.description: Approximately equal to the amount of time for the earth to make one orbit around the sun, formally defined as 365 days

shake.name: Shake
shake.description: Informal metric unit equal to 10^-8 seconds, often used in nuclear physics

K.name: Kelvin
K.description: SI standard unit with 0 defined as absolute zero

degF.name: Degrees Fahrenheit
degF.description: Temperature scale that is approximately 32 at the melting point of ice and 212 at the boiling point of water

degC.name: Degrees Celsius
degC.description: Temperature unit with a similar scale to Kelvin, but with the 0 approximately defined as the melting point of ice

Ra.name: Rankine
Ra.description: Units with the same scale as Fahrenheit, but with 0 at absolute 0

Reau.name: Reaumur
Reau.description: Temperature scale that is approximately 0 at the melting point of ice and 80 at the boiling point of water

deltaReau.name: Delta Reaumur
deltaReau.description: Change in temperature as measured in Reaumurs

kph.name: Kilometer per Hour
kph.description: Velocity at which a kilometer is traveled every hour

mph.name: Mile per Hour
mph.description: Velocity at which a mile is traveled every hour

fps.name: Feet per Second
fps.description: Velocity where 1 foot is traveled every second

knot.name: Knot
knot.description: Velocity at which a Nautical mile is traveled every hour

admkn.name: Admirality Knot
admkn.description: Knot based on the old UK definition of a Nautical mile (1853.184 m)

c.name: Speed of Light
c.description: velocity defined by how fast light travels in a vacuum

grav.name: Standard Gravity
grav.description: Approximate acceleration of gravity at the surface of the earth

galileo.name: Galileo
galileo.description: CGS system standard unit for acceleration

Pa.name: Pascal
Pa.description: SI standard unit for pressure defined as 1 N/m^2

mHg.name: Meter of Mercury
mHg.description: The pressure applied by 1 m of mercury at 1 standard gravity, more commonly used as mmHg or cmHg

mH2O.name: Meter of Water
mH2O.description: The pressure applied by 1 m of water at 1 standard gravity, more commonly used as mmH2O or cmH2O

Torr.name: Torr
Torr.description: Slightly different definition of mmHg, but very close to the same scale

psi.name: Pound per Square Inch
psi.description: US and Imperial unit of pressure defined as 1 lbf / in^2

atm.name: Atmosphere
atm.description: Approximately the mean air pressure at sea level

bar.name: Bar
bar.description: Defined as 100 000 Pa, which is very close to 1 atmosphere

inHg.name: Inch of Mercury
inHg.description: The pressure applied by 1 inch of mercury at 1 standard gravity

inH2O.name: Inch of Water
inH2O.description: The pressure applied by 1 inch of water at 1 standard gravity

ftHg.name: Foot of Mercury
ftHg.description: The pressure applied by 1 foot of mercury at 1 standard gravity

ftH2O.name: Foot of Water
ftH2O.description: The pressure applied by 1 foot of water at 1 standard gravity

Pa-g.name: Gauge Pascal
Pa-g.description: Pascal with a zero offset at atmospheric pressure

bar-g.name: Gauge Bar
bar-g.description: Bar with a zero offset at atmospheric pressure

psi-g.name: Gauge PSI
psi-g.description: psi with a zero offset at atmospheric pressure

N.name: Newton
N.description: SI standard unit for force defined as 1 kg m / s^2

dyn.name: Dyne
dyn.description: CGS standard unit for force defined as 1 g [c]m / s^2

gf.name: Gram Force
gf.description: Defined as the amount of force exerted by standard gravity on a 1 gram mass

lbf.name: Pound Force
lbf.description: Defined as the amount of force exerted by standard gravity on a 1 lbm mass

pdl.name: Poundal
pdl.description: Force unit in the foot-pound-second system equal to 1 lbm ft / s^2

J.name: Joule
J.description: SI standard unit for energy defined as 1 N m

eV.name: Electron Volt
eV.description: Energy gain of an electron after passing through a 1 Volt potential

erg.name: Erg
erg.description: CGS standard unit of energy defined as 1 dyn cm

cal.name: Calorie
cal.description: Based on the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water 1 degree Celsius, defined in The Fifth International Conference on the Properties of Steam (London, July 1956) 'International Table'

Cal.name: Kilo-calorie
Cal.description: Commonly used to measure the energy in food in the US, equal to 1000 calories and often refered to as a 'calorie' rather than a kilo-calorie

BTU.name: British Thermal Unit
BTU.description: Based on the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of 1 lbm of water 1 degree Fahrenheit, defined in The Fifth International Conference on the Properties of Steam (London, July 1956) 'International Table'

thm.name: Therm
thm.description: Unit of energy equal to 100 000 BTU, approximately the energy equivalent of burning 100 ft^3 of natural gas

Wh.name: Watt-hour
Wh.description: Amount of energy dissipated by 1 Watt source over an hour

HPh.name: Horse Power Hour
HPh.description: Amount of energy dissipated by a 1 HP source over an hour

ft-lb.name: Foot Pound-force
ft-lb.description: Defined as 1 ft x 1 lbf, typically used to describe torques rather than energy

RSI.name: R Value (SI)
RSI.description: Thermal insulation defined as 1 K m^2 / W

RIP.name: R Value (Foot Pound)
RIP.description: Thermal insulation defined as 1 Ra ft^2 hr / BTU

clo.name: Clothing
clo.description: Thermal insulation unit used in clothing design, defined as the amount of insulation that allows a person at rest to maintain thermal equilibrium in an 21 degC, normally ventilated room

tog.name: Tog
tog.description: Thermal insulation unit defined as exactly 0.1 K m^2 / W

W.name: Watt
W.description: SI standard unit for energy, defined as 1 J / s

PS.name: Metric Horsepower
PS.description: Defined as the amount of power to raise a mass of 75 kg against standard gravity over a distance of 1 meter in one second

rhe.name: Rhe
rhe.description: CGS unit for fluidity, equal to exactly 1 P^-1

tsp.name: Teaspoon
tsp.description: US Customary volume unit that is close to 5 mL

tspm.name: Metric Teaspoon
tspm.description: Based on the US Teaspoon, but defined as exactly 5 mL

tbs.name: Tablespoon
tbs.description: US Customary volume unit that is defined as 3 tsp

fl_oz.name: Fluid Ounce
fl_oz.description: US Customary volume unit that is defined as 2 tbs

uk_fl_oz.name: UK Fluid Ounce
uk_fl_oz.description: Imperial unit approximately equal to the volume of 1 avoirdupois ounce of water

cup.name: Cup
cup.description: US Customary volume unit that is defined as 8 fluid ounces

pt.name: Pint
pt.description: US Customary volume unit that is defined as 2 cups

uk_pt.name: UK Pint
uk_pt.description: Imperial volume unit defined as 20 imperial ounces

qt.name: Quart
qt.description: US Customary volume unit that is defined as 2 pints

uk_qt.name: UK Quart
uk_qt.description: Imperial volume unit defined as 2 UK pints

gal.name: Gallon
gal.description: US Customary volume unit that is defined as 4 quarts

uk_gal.name: UK Gallon
uk_gal.description: Imperial volume unit defined as 4 UK quarts

bushel.name: Bushel
bushel.description: Very old unit of volume that is associated with agricultural production, about 2150.42 in^3

bbl.name: Oil Barrel
bbl.description: Defined internationally as 42 US Gallons, typically used in the oil industry

beerbarrel.name: US Beer Barrel
beerbarrel.description: Volume associated with beer trade in the US, equal to 31 US Gallons

uk_beerbarrel.name: Imperial Beer Barrel
uk_beerbarrel.description: Appoximate volume of a barrel used for transporting beer in the UK, equal to 36 imperial gallons

MTON.name: Measurement Ton
MTON.description: Commonly used in the freight industry, equal to 40 ft^3

GRT.name: Gross Register Tonnage
GRT.description: commonly used in the freight industry equal to 100 ft^3

gill.name: Gill
gill.description: US Customary unit of volume equal to 4 US fluid ounces

uk_gill.name: UK Gill
uk_gill.description: Imperial unit equal to 5 Imperial (UK) fluid ounces

peck.name: Peck
peck.description: US Customary unit for non-fluid volume, defined as 2 dry gallons

dry_gal.name: Dry Gallon
dry_gal.description: US Customary unit for non-fluid volume, defined as exactly 268.8025 cubic inches

dry_qt.name: Dry Quart
dry_qt.description: US Customary unit for non-fluid volume, defined as 1/4 of a dry gallon

dry_pt.name: Dry Pint
dry_pt.description: US Customary unit for non-fluid volume, defined as 1/8 of a dry gallon

stere.name: Stere
stere.description: Equal to exactly 1 m^3, typically used to measure large quantities of firewood

morgen.name: Morgen
morgen.description: Traditionally the area able to be plowed in a single day by a single bladed plow and an ox or horse, it now is approximately equal to 1/4 of a hectare

acre.name: Acre
acre.description: Traditionally defined as the amount of area that could be plowed in one day by a yoke of oxen, still in use in the US

uk_acre.name: UK Acre
uk_acre.description: Slightly different than the US Acre, used in the UK until 1995

ha.name: Hectare
ha.description: Internationally used metric unit for measurement of the area of land, equal to 1000 m^3

barn.name: Barn
barn.description: Equal to 10^-28 m^2, originally used in nuclear physics for expressing the cross sectional area of nuclei and nuclear reactions

b.name: Bit
b.description: Basic unit of information that can take one of 2 states (on/off, 0/1, high/low)

B.name: Byte
B.description: Equal to 8 bits of information, commonly used in modern computing architectures

dword.name: Double Word
dword.description: Equal to 32 bits, 4 bytes or 2 words

baud.name: Baud Rate
baud.description: Rate of data transmission equal to 1 bit / second

A.name: Ampere
A.description: SI standard unit for electric current, equal to 1 C/s

C.name: Coulomb
C.description: SI standard unit for electric charge defined as the amount of charge of exactly 6.2415093e18 elementary charges

Ah.name: Amp Hour
Ah.description: Charge collected from 1 Amp over 1 hour

e.name: Elementary Charge
e.description: The electric charge carried by a single proton

V.name: Volt
V.description: Derived SI unit for electric potential, can be defined as J/C

ohm.name: Ohm
ohm.description: Derived SI unit for electrical resistance

F.name: Farad
F.description: Derived SI unit of electrical capacitance

S.name: Siemens
S.description: Derived SI unit for electrical conductance, equal to 1 / ohm

Wb.name: Weber
Wb.description: SI unit for magnetic flux defined as 1 kg m^2 / (s^2 A)

Mx.name: Maxwell
Mx.description: CGS unit for magnetic flux defined as 1 g cm^2 / (s^2 A)

T.name: Tesla
T.description: SI unit for magnetic flux density defined as 1 Wb / m^2

Gs.name: Gauss
Gs.description: CGS unit for magnetic flux density defined as 1 Mx / cm^2

Fr.name: Franklin
Fr.description: Standard unit of electrical charge in the EMU-CGS units of measure

Gi.name: Gilbert
Gi.description: Obsolete unit used in EMU-CGS systems to measure magnetization, dimensionally equivalent to the Amp

Oe.name: Oersted
Oe.description: CGS unit of auxiliary magnetic field

mol.name: Mole
mol.description: SI standard unit for an amount of substance, defined as exactly 6.02214076e23 elementary entities (usually molecules)

molar.name: Molar Concentration
molar.description: Amount of substance per Liter of solution

kat.name: Katal
kat.description: Unit of catalytic activity, defined as 1 mol / sec

U.name: Enzyme
U.description: Unit of catalytic activity, defined as 1 [u]mol / min

cd.name: Candela
cd.description: SI standard unit for luminous intensity in a given direction defined by taking the fixed numerical value of the luminous efficacy of monochromatic radiation of frequency 540e12 Hz

lm.name: Lumen
lm.description: SI derived unit of luminous flux, a measure of the total quantity of visible light emitted by a source. 1 lm = 1 cd sr

lx.name: Lux
lx.description: SI derived unit of illuminance, measuring luminous flux per unit area. 1 lx = 1 lm/m^2)

footlambert.name: Footlambert
footlambert.description: Non-SI unit of illuminance or light intensity. 1 footcandle = 1 lm / ft^2

lambert.name: Lambert
lambert.description: Non-SI unit of luminance. 1 lambert = 1/ cd / cm^2

rad.name: Radian
rad.description: Defined as the ratio of the radius of a circular arc to the radius of the arc, typically used to describe angles

sr.name: Steradians
sr.description: A 'square radian' is a unit of solid angle analogous to the radian, a solid angle of 1 sr projected onto a unit sphere will have unit area

rev.name: Revolution
rev.description: Angle describing one full revolution around an axis

deg.name: Degree
deg.description: Angle measurement equal to 1/360 of a revolution

arcmin.name: Arc Minute
arcmin.description: Angle measurement defined as 1/60 of a degree

arcsec.name: Arc Second
arcsec.description: Angle measurement defined as 1/60 of a arc minue

rpm.name: Revolutions per Minute
rpm.description: Rotational frequency describing the number of revolution around an axis in a minute

Hz.name: Hertz
Hz.description: Frequency defined as 1 (cycle or rotation) / sec

Bq.name: Becquerel
Bq.description: SI derived unit for radiation activity

Gy.name: Gray
Gy.description: SI derived unit for radiation absorbed dose

Sv.name: Sievert
Sv.description: SI unit for radiation equivalent dose, although dimensionally equivalent to Gy, it also includes a weighting function for types of radiation effects on human cells, and is thus not exactly equal

RAD.name: Radiation Absorbed Dose
RAD.description: Conventional unit for radiation absorbed dose

rem.name: Roentgen Equivalent Man
rem.description: Conventional unit for radiation equivalent dose
